dt: {bc}{a_link|therapeutic} medical treatment of impairment, injury, disease, or disorder

dt.t: The number of new patients treated for end-stage renal disease … with dialysis or renal transplantation has continued to rise exponentially with an 8.4% annualized growth rate reaching more than 160,000 patients undergoing {wi}therapy{/wi} in the United States in 1989.

dt: {dx}see also {dxt|art therapy||}, {dxt|chelation therapy||}, {dxt|chemotherapy||}, {dxt|chemotherapy||}, {dxt|gene therapy||}, {dxt|hormone therapy||}, {dxt|music therapy||}, {dxt|occupational therapy||}, {dxt|physical therapy||}, {dxt|shock therapy||}, {dxt|speech therapy||} {/dx}

dt.t: Furthermore, the psychotherapist knows that all actions in {wi}therapy{/wi} are messages that need be decoded and understood regardless of the 'language' the patient uses.

aq.auth: Bruno Bettelheim and Alvin A. Rosenfeld

shortdef: therapeutic medical treatment of impairment, injury, disease, or disorder

dt: {bc}therapy for prostate cancer that severely reduces the body's production of {d_link|androgens|androgen} and especially testosterone through the administration of drugs or through surgical removal of the testicles

shortdef: therapy for prostate cancer that severely reduces the body's production of androgens and especially testosterone through the administration of drugs or through surgical removal of the testicles

dt: {bc}therapy based on engagement in artistic activities (such as painting or drawing) as a means of creative expression and symbolic communication especially in individuals affected with a mental or emotional disorder or cognitive impairment

dt.t: She's also used {wi}art therapy{/wi} while working with autistic and special-needs children and patients recovering from strokes.

In {wi}art therapy{/wi}, patients express their feelings not just through discussion, but through drawing, painting and sculpting. That's why this type of therapy is thought to be especially helpful for people who have difficulty articulating feelings—including children and those suffering from Alzheimer's disease, strokes and post-traumatic stress disorder.

utxt.t: Although she works toward the same goals as the psychologist or psychiatrist, as an {wi}art therapist{/wi} her technique is decidedly different.

shortdef: therapy based on engagement in artistic activities (such as painting or drawing) as a means of creative expression and symbolic communication especially in individuals affected with a mental or emotional disorder or cognitive impairment

dt: {bc}therapy intended to suppress an undesirable habit or behavior (such as smoking) by associating the habit or behavior with a noxious or punishing stimulus (such as electric shock)

shortdef: therapy intended to suppress an undesirable habit or behavior (such as smoking) by associating the habit or behavior with a noxious or punishing stimulus (such as electric shock)

dt: {bc}psychotherapy that is concerned with the treatment (as by desensitization or aversion therapy) of observable behaviors rather than underlying psychological processes and that applies principles of learning to substitute desirable responses and behavior patterns for undesirable ones (such as phobias or obsessions) {dx}compare {dxt|cognitive therapy|cognitive therapy|}{/dx}

shortdef: psychotherapy that is concerned with the treatment (as by desensitization or aversion therapy) of observable behaviors rather than underlying psychological processes and that applies principles of learning to substitute desirable responses and behavior patterns for undesirable ones (such as phobias or obsessions)

dt: {bc}the use of a chelator (such as EDTA) to bind with a metal (such as lead or iron) in the body to form a chelate so that the metal loses its chemical effect (such as toxicity or physiological activity)

shortdef: the use of a chelator (such as EDTA) to bind with a metal (such as lead or iron) in the body to form a chelate so that the metal loses its chemical effect (such as toxicity or physiological activity)

dt: {bc}psychotherapy that emphasizes the substitution of desirable patterns of thinking for maladaptive or faulty ones

shortdef: psychotherapy that emphasizes the substitution of desirable patterns of thinking for maladaptive or faulty ones; especially : cognitive behavioral therapy —abbreviation CT

dt: {bc}the use of any of various methods (such as {d_link|aversive|aversive} stimulation or religious counseling) in an attempt to change a person's sexual orientation to heterosexual or to change a person's {d_link|gender identity|gender identity} to correspond to the sex the person has or was identified as having at birth
Conversion therapy is generally regarded as having no scientific basis and as being both ineffective and harmful.

dt.t: {wi}Conversion therapy{/wi} is both pointless and painful. At its best, it can inflict considerable psychological damage on a child without changing their sexual orientation or gender identity whatsoever. At its worst, it can lead to suicide …
Momentum has been building in legislative sessions this spring for the bans, which prohibit state-licensed mental health professionals from practicing {wi}conversion therapy{/wi} for anyone under 18.

shortdef: the use of any of various methods (such as aversive stimulation or religious counseling) in an attempt to change a person's sexual orientation to heterosexual or to change a person's gender identity to correspond to the sex the person has or was identified as having at birth —called also reparative therapy

dt: {bc}the treatment of mental illness and especially depression by the application of electric current to the head of a usually anesthetized patient that induces unconsciousness and convulsive seizures in the brain

shortdef: the treatment of mental illness and especially depression by the application of electric current to the head of a usually anesthetized patient that induces unconsciousness and convulsive seizures in the brain —called also electroconvulsive therapy
